title: The Cheese and the Worms
author: Carlo Ginzburg
review_text: An absolutely extraordinary work of recovery and reconstruction.

title: In Search of Canadian Political Culture
author: Nelson Wiseman
review_text: If you want a series of absolutely disjointed, English-Canadian-Boomer-centrist musings on Canadian politics, look no further. 2 stars because it occasionally describes something accurate.

title: Red Skin, White Masks
author: Glen Sean Coulthard
review_text: There is no work with more explanatory power when it comes to the basic dynamics of Canadian politics, in the broadest sense, in the 21st century.

title: A History of Contemporary Italy: Society and Politics, 1943-1988
author: Paul Ginsborg
review_text: Simply one of the best historical works I've ever read, and the single best on Italy. Comprehensive, but fluidly written; vivid in its use of individual or local experience to illustrate wider themes; incredibly precise--and usually convincing--in argumentation.

title: Falling Hour
author: Geoffrey D Morrison
review_text: Impossible to believe this won't be a cult classic.

title: The Patriots and the People: The Rebellion of 1837 in Rural Lower Canada (Heritage)
author: Allan Greer
review_text: My only complaint is that in the early chapters on rural community life, the connection to the wider argument sometimes disappears into the thick of case-study details, but this is a hazard of sufficiently careful social history.

title: Zapata and the Mexican Revolution
author: John Womack Jr.
review_text: Fantastic book; I feel like I have a better understanding not only of Zapata or the Mexican Revolution but of Mexico and of peasant revolutions more generally. I also wish historians let themselves *write* like this still.
